subject: Relationships
title: Friendship in Midlife: The Great Pruning
description: A micro-lesson that makes Friendship in Midlife: The Great Pruning usable.

hook.text: At 40, most people have half the friends they had at 25. And for the first time, that feels like a choice.

buildup.text: Socioemotional selectivity theory says we naturally narrow our social circles as we age â€” prioritizing quality.

discovery.text: Midlife friendships that survive the pruning are stronger. They're chosen, not inherited from circumstance.

twist.text: The pruning can go too far. Some people isolate entirely, mistaking selectivity for self-sufficiency.

climax.text: Midlife friendship is an art of curation. Keep the ones who fill your cup. Release the ones who drain it.

punchline.text: By 40, you have fewer friends. The ones left are the ones that matter.

quiz.question: What is socioemotional selectivity theory?
options: We make more friends as we age
We naturally narrow social circles to prioritize quality
